title: 900-keep-safe-places-available-scotland
story: TODAYis International Day of Persons with Disabilities and Police Scotland say that they aim to ensure that people with disabilities or long-term conditions, both visible and hidden, are able to access their police service when they need it.Previously people with disabilities have told officers that they sometimes feel less safe where they live.In response Police Scotland say that they are working with local communities to create Keep Safe places for anyone feeling vulnerable when out in the community. There are currently over  across Scotland and the network continues to grow.Officers also say that taking part in the lsquoYour Police Surveyrsquo is one way for people to express their views and needs.Responses to Your Police Survey helps officers identy and eliminate obstacles and barriers for anyone who needs them and they would encourage everyone to take part to influence policing in their area.Your Police Survey is available in easy read and British Sign Language formats.Take part here http:ow.ly BXwHPh

title: massive-game-ahead-vale-leithen
story: VALE of Leithento Lowland League action on Saturday with a trip to face in-form Stirling University.And manager Grant Sandison believes thathis players continue with the same form that they displayed in their last two league games then they are more than capable of causing problems for the students.Vale have not played a competitive game since November  due to having been eliminated in the early stages of the South Challenge Cup and the Scottish Cup.During that break Sandison has been completing his UEFA B Licence Course at the Oriam in Edinburgh and he managed to arrange a couple of friendlies to keep the squad ticking over.Last week Vale lost - to Peebles Rovers and on Tuesday a match against Preston Athletic was abandoned due to adverse weather.Stirling have been in a good run of form recently beating Gala Fairydean Rovers - at Netherdale in the South Challenge Cup."When I first took over, they were down the bottom of the table along with Gretna and Edinburgh University," Sandison said. ldquoBut they have picked up lately and are showing consistency. They are in a good run of form and have done well, taking eight points from their last four games and are in a  position in the table.ldquoI watched them against East Stirling and had them watched against Gala so we are well briefed and I know they have some good young players but I believe thatwe can take the level of performance we showed against Bonnyrigg and Spartans then we can cause them problems.ldquoWe have a couple of things in the pipeline including a possible loan signing and hopefully it will happen before Saturday.

title: coronavirus-borders-recorded-60-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirus in a -hour period, latest figures show.An update was published by the Scottish Government at pm today .And the new data shows that the Borders has now seen , coronavirus cases since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed cases of COVID-, one fewer than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases since March last year.

title: galashiels-great-tapestry-ticket-sale-figures-really-good
story: FIGURES around the number of tickets sold for the Great Tapestry centre have been described as ldquoreally good.The visitor attraction, which opened in Galashiels in August, was discussed at a full council meeting on Thursday, November .During the open questions section of the virtual gathering, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott asked how many paying customers have visited and how much revenue had been made.Responding, fellow Galashiels councillor Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said that , tickets have been bought, with pound, generated since its opening to the public.According to Mr Jardine, those numbers are ldquoin line with the revised business case projections made in February which included coronavirus implications on visitor numbers.Mr Scott, an independent representative, said: ldquoThatrsquos quite gratying. In these dficult times those figures are very good.ldquoI look forward to the facility enjoying better times ahead.Ahead of the centre opening, the council said it would ldquoattract over , visitors to Galashiels each year ndash creating  jobs and almost pound, of extra spending per annum.

title: electric-vehicle-charging-points-borders-report-recommend-fee
story: OWNERS of electric vehicles in the Borders could soon have to pay to charge their vehicle, it has been revealed.Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, told a meeting last week that an upcoming report will recommend the local authority charges for the service.The plans could be put to elected officials as early as January, according to Mr Edgar.Responding to an open question from Hawick representative Davie Paterson on the issue, the independent councillor said: ldquoA condition of earlier Transport Scotland grant funding for electric vehicle charging points was that they were free at the point to encourage the uptake of electric vehicles.ldquoThis condition has now been removed and Scottish Borders Council, like other local authorities, should be considering introducing a charging regime.He added: ldquoA report on the issue is currently being prepared and will recommend that the council introduces a charging regime going forward.Mr Edgar told the meeting that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was pound,.Meanwhile, Borders MP John Lamont says that an out of order charging point at Tweedbank Railway Station is ldquonot helping people in the Borders use electric vehicles.Figures from the Department for Transport show that there are a total of  electric vehicle charging devices available for public use in the region.But Mr Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, says the station charger has been out of action for two months.ldquoI am keen to see electric vehicle use become more practical for people in the Scottish Borders, he said. ldquoHowever, cases like the broken charging point at Tweedbank Station are not helping.ldquoWe need to make sure we have a fully-ing electric vehicle charging network. That is why I have written to Scottish Borders Council to try and get the charging point fixed as quickly as possible..removeldquoAs we continue to increase the number of EV charging points here in the Borders, we must ensure that they are well maintained.The Borders is set to benefit from pound, of UK Government funding to support the development of electric vehicle charging points, according to Mr Lamont.On the funding, he said: ldquoI am very pleased that almost pound, of funding will go towards the expansion of our EV charging point network as part of the UKrsquos community renewal fund.ldquoI also appreciate that Scottish Borders Council will be taking on the responsibility of looking after them.

title: peebles-high-quality-path-network-plans-lodged-council
story: PEEBLES could be set for a number of ldquohigh quality walking trails after plans were filed with the council.Proposals to improve the current network while also creating new paths are outlined in an application prepared by Laurence Gould Partnership Ltd at the request of Benson Wemyss Farms.The current situation in the area to the west of the town is ldquonot ideal, providing an opportunity to link to other routes and improve ldquothe overall quality of the local path network.ldquoThe farm is a strong supporter of hillwalking and public access, having set up the highly successful Tweed Walk in partnership with Border Council [Scottish Borders Council], and has applied to the Agri-Environment  Climate Scheme for grant aid in order to improve public access across the farm, providing improved links and connectivity, improved path conditions and accessible paths for all, a report submitted as part of the application reads.ldquoThe farm has a number of existing footpaths that will be improved via the scheme, but the scheme will also create a number of new footpaths for users to enjoy.ldquoPeebles is rapidly becoming a destination for enjoying the outdoors and the woods around Neidpath are increasingly used as an important asset by the community.The business is proposing to ldquoincrease the value of the path network to the local community.According to the report, the new routes proposed include linking two core paths through the Jedderfield Plantation.On that plan, the papers state: ldquoThere are a vast range of heavily used paths through these woodlands that turn to mush during the winter. This project aims to make them accessible for more people throughout the year.A new path from the southwest section of South Park Wood along the edge of the River Tweed to the Old Manor Bridge is also outlined.Existing pathways to be upgraded are located throughout South Park Wood and alongside the River Tweed, along the old Symington, Biggar, and Broughton Railway line, according to the report..removeThe business farms at Edston Farm, located immediately to the west of Peebles.Holiday lets, a horse livery and a wedding venue are currently operated by the business, the papers state.

title: borders-gift-card-proposed-help-boost-high-streets
story: PLANS for a gt card that allows you to spend money at local businesses will be discussed by senior councillors on Tuesday .The national initiative is designed to help local retailers and high streets, according to papers put to the executive committee before next weekrsquos meeting.People can choose the amount of money to load onto the gt card and spend it within businesses that have signed up to the scheme, according to Scottish Borders Council .The view from the council is that the Scotland Loves Local Gt Card initiative would be ldquoworth trying considering the dficulties businesses have experienced during the COVID- pandemic.ldquoThe idea behind the gt card is to try and encourage people to spend money in the local community, thereby helping to support local businesses and the local supply chain, the report states. ldquoLike any other gt card, you can choose the amount of money to load onto the card.ldquoHowever, the key dference in this case is that the money can only be spent within the boundaries of the Scottish Borders and with businesses that have signed up to the scheme.ldquoThe gt cards will feature a -digit MasterCard number, CVV and expiry date allowing them to be used online at independent and national retailers alike, as long as the retailer has a physical presence in the local authority area and is making a contribution to the local economy.It adds: ldquoOur understanding is that neighbouring local authorities such as Dumfries and Galloway and Midlothian councils have already signed up to the scheme and East Lothian Council already had a gt card scheme in place which they believe to be worthwhile.If approved, it will cost the council around pound, annually to market and promote the scheme, according to the papers.It is proposed that SBC trials the scheme ldquoover the short to medium term.A review of the scheme will be undertaken after a full year of operation to help gauge the success of the project, with the results then presented to elected members. The gt card project was launched in July by Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnership.

title: west-linton-host-first-live-coffee-concert
story: A BORDERS village is set to host its first live coffee concert.During the coronavirus pandemic the West Linton Village Centre hosted a number of virtual music events, however, the centre will now welcome a live audience for Twogether Duo.Twogether Duo, formed of Alena Bulatetskaya from Russia on classical accordion and Huixin Hu from China on violin, will perform a range of numbers, including classical pieces, folk songs, and Christmas favourites.And in the interval guests can enjoy a cup of coffee or tea with a choice of home-baked treats for free.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe Coffee Concerts series have been made possible courtesy of a grant awarded to the VC from the CAF Tourle Foundation and with the assistance of Live Music Now Scotland.Spaces for the Coffee Concert are limited, and tickets can be booked by emailing westlintonvillagecentre@gmail or by calling texting  . For those who are unable to attend in person, the performance will be streamed via Zoom. To register, click here.Twogether Duo will perform at West Linton Village Centre on Saturday, December  from -.pm.

title: winning-return-peebles-burgh-silver-band
story: PEEBLES Burgh Silver Band recently won the th Section of the Borders Entertainment Contest.On November  at The Buccleuch Centre in Langholm, Peebles Burgh Silver Ban joined a number of other Borders bands following the contestrsquos postponement last year due to the coronavirus pandemic.The bandrsquos musical director Peter Holmes prepared the programme which featured Philip Harperrsquos arrangement of Fat Bottom Girlsby Queen, The Road and the Miles to Dundeearranged by Alan Fernie, and I Will Follow Youfrom Sister Act.The band retained the trophy they won at the  competition.At the weekend the band performed at the annual Christmas lights switch-on in Peebles High Street.Peebles Burgh Silver Band now plans to perform on the High Street each Saturday morning throughout December from .am ndash weather permitting ndash and will host a Christmas Concert on Friday, December  in the Burgh Hall.Speaking about these upcoming events, a band spokesperson said: ldquoAll of these are much needed fundraising events for the Band following  months or so of no fundraising.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to sponsors and donors most recently The Provincial Grand Lodge of The Scottish Borders who provided a grant towards Youth Band tuition.ldquoWithout actions like this we would be unable to offer the free tuition and instruments to all.ldquoPBSB will be delighted to see you over the festive period and greatly appreciate all the local support it receives.Members of the Peebles Burgh Youth Band will also perform at the concert. Tickets for the concert can be purchased from band members or on the night.

title: christmas-arrives-peebles-switch-on-event
story: FESTIVE joy filled the streets in Peebles at the weekend as the townrsquos annual Christmas lights switch-on ed following the coronavirus pandemic.Visitors to the town and locals alike were treated to an afternoon filled with music and plenty of opportunities to find great gts.At .pm the lights were turned on by Paul Spence and Sophie Hamilton, the founders of the Peebles COVID- Mutual Support Group at the start of the pandemic.A spokesperson for Peebles Christmas Lights Association ndash which organised the event ndash shared on social media: ldquoThe people of Peebles and beyond you really are amazing, what an outstanding turnout this afternoon. We could not of wished for a better crowd of people.ldquoThe gamble well and truly paid off and our Association is very grateful.ldquoA huge thank you to all the stall holders and local businesses for their support today also, this would not of been possible without you all.ldquoThis is all put together and run by a small band of volunteers who have put hundreds of man hours into making this all possible, some of whom have been out since mid morning clearing cars from the street ready for the build up.ldquoThey all do this for the love of the town and what joy it brings to the town we try to keep everybody happy but sometimes this is just not possible.Musical performances on the day came courtesy of Peebles Burgh Silver Band, Peebles Ex-Servicemenrsquos Pipe Band, InChorus, and The Taylor Brothers. And stalls at the Christmas market along the High Street offered art, clothing, homewares and local produce.

title: weekend-rugby-round-up
story: The weather affected this weekendrsquos rugby card with a number of games postponed and one abandoned.In the Premiership, Hawick won the Borders derby beating Selkirk - at Philiphaugh. Kieran Clarkrsquos penalty gave the Souters the lead before Kirk Ford replied with a try which he converted to give the visitors a - half-time lead.Another Clark penalty reduced the deficit before referee Michael Todd awarded a penalty try to Hawick which Ford converted.A third Clark penalty finished the scoring.Jed-Forest travelled to Glasgow where they lost - to the Hawks. Captain Gregor Young suffered a rib injury forcing a change in formation then Paulo Ferreira saw yellow for a high tackle before Glasgow scored a converted try.Selkirk responded with a try from Lewis Young which Gary Munro converted then another penalty from Munro gave the Borderers a - lead.A converted try and a penalty from the Hawks secured the victory despite late pressure from Glasgow.In National League Division One Biggar beat Stirling Wolves - at Hartree Mill, Gala beat Ayr - at Netherdale, Kelso lost - to Highland in Inverness and the Melrose game against Boroughmuir was abandoned.In National League Division Two, Peebles game against Kirkcaldy was postponed.In National League Division Three Berwickrsquos game against Murrayfield Wanderers was abandoned.In National East League One Duns lost - to Broughton.In National East League Two Hawick Lindenrsquos game against Leith was postponed.In National East League Three Earlston lost - to Edinburgh Northern.In Reserve East League One Selkirk A lost - to Hawick Force at home and Jed-Forest A lost - away to Stewartrsquos Melville in the capital.In Reserve East League Two Kelso Sharks drew - with Gala A, Melrose Storm beat Preston Lodge - in Prestonpans and Peebles Reds game against Edinburgh Accies was postponed.In the Semi-Junior Borders League Kelso Harlequins beat Morpeth Colts - away from home.

title: covid-scotland-negative-lateral-flow-accepted-place-vaccine-passport-today
story: Negative lateral flow test resultswill be accepted in venues that require vaccine passports from today, after changes were made to the scheme by the Scottish government.Currently in Scotland you are required to show proof that you are fully vaccinatedfor entry intonightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.But from today a negative lateral flow test result at these venues will also be accepted.Heres everything you need to know...Can I use a lateral flow test to enter venues requiring a vaccine passport Yes, from Monday December , you can use proof of a negative lateral flow testto enter venues on the vaccine passport scheme in Scotland.Proof of vaccination will also still be accepted for these venues.If using a lateral flow test, it must have been taken within -hours prior to entry.You must report your lateral flow test result on the government website.How do I report my lateral flow test When you take your lateral flow test, you must report it on the Government website, which can be found here.You will then be sent a text or email confirming your result which can be used -negative - for entry to events requiring vaccine certication.Where can I get lateral flow tests Lateral flow tests are available for free from pharmacies and to order from the Scottish government website.Nicola Sturgeon also said that lateral flow tests would become available to collect in more venues in Scotland, including Christmas markets and sport centres.How can I download proof of vaccination You can download your vaccine passporton your smartphonevia theNHS Scotland Covid Status App.Alternatively, you can order a paper copyof your vaccine passport via yourvaccine portalor phoningthe specially designated Covid status helpline on  , open from am-pm every day..removeWill my booster jab show on my vaccine passport At the moment in Scotland, your booster vaccine will not show on your vaccine passport.However, the Scottish government has said it is working to change this as soon as possible to ensure the booster does appear on your vaccination certication.

title: stormont-assembly-debate-ban-hunting-dogs-northern-ireland
story: Stormont MLAs are set to debate whether to ban hunting with dogs in Northern Ireland.The region remains the only part of the UK where hunting wild mammals with dogs is still permitted.A private membersrsquo bill brought by Alliance MLA John Blair aims to bring Northern Ireland into line with the rest of the UK.However the Countryside Alliance has urged MLAs to vote against the bill, describing it as ldquovery clumsily cobbled together with absolutely no regard or thought for its wider implication.Speaking ahead of the debate, Stormont Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots indicated he would not be supporting the bill.vw,vw,px, px"Alliance Party MLA John Blair Mr Poots contended foxes are a threat to some ground-nesting birds such as red grouse and hen harriers.ldquoIf wersquore serious about bioersity, then we need to have management tools and we need to be very cautious about removing management tools, he told BBC Radio Ulster.ldquoIrsquom not sure it is a particularly well written bill so I canrsquot support it on that basis. Personally I donrsquot hunt, I donrsquot particularly like hunting but I canrsquot support this particular bill because I think that it isnrsquot well thought through. It might be well meaning but not well thought through and has damaging consequencesit came into force.Hunting with dogs has been banned in England, Scotland, and Wales since the early s.The bill will be open for debate on the floor of the Assembly on Monday after gaining signicant support during a public consultation with nearly % of the , respondents in favour of a ban.It is understood to be the largest consultation response in Stormontrsquos history.The bill has been backed by the Northern Ireland animal welfare charity, the USPCA.Mr Blair said: ldquoNorthern Ireland is the only part of the United Kingdom without a ban on hunting with dogs, despite widespread public support to ban the practice.ldquoIt is my intention in bringing forward my Private Memberrsquos Bill, to reform legislation on hunting wild mammals with dogs in Northern Ireland, and bring our legislation in line with that in England, Scotland and Wales where the practice has been illegal for close to  years..removevw,vw,px, px"USPCA chief executive Brendan Mullan Chief executive Brendan Mullan said the charity has been ldquogreatly encouraged by the momentum around this bill.ldquoThe appetite of the public to end this cruel practice which causes unthinkable pain and suffering for innocent wild animals, he said.ldquoIt must be recognised that, now, with the bill being presented to the Assembly, we are coming to a pivotal juncture for animal welfare here in Northern Ireland, which will set the tone for our future.ldquoThere is a real opportunity here for the Assembly to put on record their commitment to enhancing animal welfare standards, and specically on this occasion, introducing legislation which has been in place in other regions for nearly  years.ldquoThe arguments against banning hunting wild mammals with dogs are based on tradition and pest control however it is categorically clear that the cruelty involved in this activity far outweighs any supposed benefit.ldquoMoreover, the rationalisation regarding pest control is tenuous at best as there is no evidence of this being the case.ldquoIn England for example, the ban has been in place for quite some time and an inquiry taken forward at Westminster has stated that the contribution of fox hunting is almost insignicant in terms of managing the fox population as a whole.Mr Mullan added: ldquoThis issue has been a key focus of the USPCA for a number of years, with our goal for the introduction of a ban outlined in our Animal Welfare Manesto lsquoAddressing the Deficitrsquo.ldquoMembers of the public have made their views on this barbaric lsquosportrsquo very clear, and we look forward to the Assemblyrsquos response which we hope will consign it to the pages of history for Northern Ireland. Killing defenceless wild mammals with dogs is sadistic and cruel and has no place in a compassionate society.But Gary McCartney, director of Countryside Alliance Ireland, which opposes the bill, contended that it could ldquopotentially criminalise every dog owner in Northern Ireland and ldquoalso represents an attack on the rural way of le.ldquoAnyone whose dog chases a rabbit or squirrel, for example, whilst they are simply out for a walk in the park, partaking in country pursuits, checking their livestock or engaged in any other activity will be committing a criminal offence, he said.ldquoWe are continuing to urge MLAs to oppose this bill..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Stormont Assembly to debate ban on hunting with dogs in Northern Ireland

title: omicron-know-new-covid-19-variant
story: The emergence of the new coronavirus iant known as Omicron has already impacted travel rules and sparked ato compulsory mask-wearing on public transport.Some  cases of Omicron ndash also known as B... ndash were confirmed in the UK as of Sunday.But what do we know about the new strain so far, and what could it mean for future restrictions ndash How would you knowyou have contracted the Omicron strain People with Covid- symptoms should take a PCR test, and scientists can determine which strain they have contractedit is positive.This requires genetic analysis in a laboratory and can take up to  days.vw,vw,px, px"Positive PCR tests can be analysed by scientists in a laboratory to determine which iant a person has contracted Not all UK labs are equipped with the technology needed to identy Omicron cases, which means some parts of the country will be able to track the sp easily than others.Rapid or lateral flow tests cannot tell you which iant you have been infected with, but scientists believe they will still reflect a positive resultyou have the Omicron iant.ndash When did Omicron first appear UK scientists became aware of the new strain on November , after samples were uploaded to a coronavirus iant tracking website from South Africa, Hong Kong and then Botswana.The World Health Organisationdesignated it a ldquoiant of concern on November , because it has several mutations which mean it is more dficult to predict how it will behave.ndash How is Omicron dferent to other iants The latest iant involves mutations on the spike protein of the virus, which is the part targeted by most vaccines.vw,vw,px, px"According to the Office for National Statistics , scientists dferentiate Omicron from other iants by identying patterns among three genes in positive results ndash the S gene, the ORFab gene and the N gene.Delta iant infections usually test positive for all three genes, whereas the Omicron iant is known to test negative for the S gene..removendash Is Omicron more deadly or transmissible than previous iants It is unclear whether Omicron is more transmissible compared with other iants, including the dominant Delta strain, according to the WHO.The number of people testing positive for coronavirus has risen in areas of South Africa affected by the iant, and studies have begun to determine whether this is because it is more easily passed on.It is also unclear whether Omicron is likely to cause more deaths or severe disease, and understanding this is likely to take several more weeks, the WHO has said.ndash What are the symptoms of Omicron The WHO has said there is no evidence that symptoms associated with Omicron are dferent to those of other iants.vw,vw,px, px"There have been  Omicron cases identied in the UK so far Initial reported infections in South Africa were among university students who had a mild disease ndash but this is common among the younger age group for all iants.The most common Covid- symptoms are still a cough, fever and a loss of smell or taste.ndash How many cases have been confirmed in the UK The UK Health Security Agency said a further  cases of Omicron had been confirmed in the UK on Sunday,  in England and  in Scotland, bringing the total to .Professor Mark Woolhouse, who is a member of the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group on Modellingwhich advises the Government, has said Omicron is ldquospreading pretty rapidly and the figure will rise.ndash What are the concerns about Omicron and when will we knowthey are well-founded There are concerns around transmissibility, severity of illness and vaccine efficacy.Deputy chief medical officer for England Professor Jonathan Van-Tam said scientists around the world agree that the Omicron iant is ldquoof increased concern.vw,vw,px, px"Professor Jonathan Van Tam has warnedthat Omicron could be more transmissible than previous iants He said there are still uncertainties about how transmissible the iant is and its impact on severity of disease.He said the ldquonumber of mutations present, already on first principle, makes us worry about a possible effect on vaccine effectiveness.He made clear that there ldquoare far more things we donrsquot know yet, than things we do know about the iant, but that he expects more to become clear in two weeks.ndash What is happening in the UK as scientists work to find out more about Omicron The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationis now advising that all adults aged  to  should be offered a Covid- booster dose, in order of descending age groups, to increase their level of protection.Early evidence suggests that higher antibody levels may give better protection against the iant.Booster doses should be given no sooner than three months after people have had their second dose of an original vaccine ndash shaving three months off the current six-month wait.Meanwhile, young people aged  to  should be offered a second dose of the Pfizer BioNTech Covid- vaccine, no sooner than  weeks after their first dose.ndash Have any new measures been introduced in the UK The Government has tightened rules around PCR tests for travellers ing to the UK and introduced quarantine rules for people from high-risk countries, as well as bringing back face coverings in shops and on public transport in England.It has also accelerated the Covid booster programme to help slow down the spread of the new iant.vw,vw,px, px"Face coverings are once again compulsory inside shops in England Scotlandrsquos First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, and Walesrsquos First Minister, Mark Drakeford, have demanded that a tougher four-nations approach is adopted.Downing Street rejected calls from Ms Sturgeon and Mr Drakeford for the self-isolation period for travellers to be extended until the result of a test on day eight after arriving in the UK.Extending the requirements would have a ldquodetrimental effect on the travel industry, No  said.Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have all implemented travel rules for non-red list arrivals.ndash What do tightened rules mean for Christmas parties Although there are no official bans on large gatherings, scientists have urged people to act cautiously.Professor Robert West, a member of the Scientic Pandemic Insights Group on Behaviours , encouraged revellers to make ldquoflexible plans for the holiday period.vw,vw,px, px"Despite tightened restrictions in England, there are no bans on gatherings for Christmas parties He told Sky News last week he personally would not make plans ldquothat involve gatherings that canrsquot be changed.Prof West said: ldquoIn other words, keep flexible. Make your plans, by all means, as I am, but do it in a way which means that should the worst come to the worst, and we have to make sure that people stay apart from each other as much as possible as is safe, then you can still enjoy the holiday period.ndash What about working from home England is the only UK nation where working from home is not encouraged.Ms Sturgeon reminded people in Scotland on Monday to ldquowork from homepossible.The advice is the same in Northern Ireland, and working from home is encouraged under current guidance in Wales.Previously the Prime Ministerrsquos spokesman has said it was up to employers to decide on the ldquoright balance for them, when it came to whether staff worked from home or the office.Jurisdiction over coronavirus restrictions is devolved, meaning Prime Minister Boris Johnsonrsquos policies apply to England, and may dfer from the rules where in the UK..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Omicron: What do we know about the new Covid- iant

title: covid-scotland-negative-lateral-flow-accepted-place-vaccine-passport-today
story: Negative lateral flow test resultswill be accepted in venues that require vaccine passports from today, after changes were made to the scheme by the Scottish government.Currently in Scotlandyou are required to show proof that you are fully vaccinatedfor entry intonightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.But from today a negative lateral flow test result at these venues will also be accepted.Heres everything you need to know...Can I use a lateral flow test to enter venues requiring a vaccine passport Yes, from Monday December , you can use proof of a negative lateral flow testto enter venues on the vaccine passport scheme in Scotland.Proof of vaccination will also still be accepted for these venues.If using a lateral flow test, it must have been taken within -hours prior to entry.You must report your lateral flow test result on the government website.How do I report my lateral flow test When you take your lateral flow test, you must report it on the Government website, which can be found here.You will then be sent a text or email confirming your result which can be used -negative - for entry to events requiring vaccine certication.Where can I get lateral flow tests Lateral flow tests are available for free from pharmacies and to order from the Scottish government website.Nicola Sturgeon also said that lateral flow tests would become available to collect in more venues in Scotland, including Christmas marketsand sport centres.How can I download proof of vaccination You can download your vaccine passporton your smartphonevia theNHS Scotland Covid Status App.Alternatively, you can order a paper copyof your vaccine passport via yourvaccine portalor phoningthe specially designated Covid status helpline on  , open from am-pm every day..removeWill my booster jab show on my vaccine passport At the moment in Scotland, your booster vaccine will not show on your vaccine passport.However, the Scottish government has said it is working to change this as soon as possible to ensure the booster does appear on your vaccination certication.

title: new-travel-rules-scotland---changes-covid-travel-restrictions
story: More changes to the Covid travelrules in the UK have been introduced amid concerns surrounding the Omicron iant.Scientists are racing to understand more about the new iant originally identied in South Africa, with fears that it could be more transmissible than Delta.In order to try and curb the spread of Omicron, new travel rules have been imposed around the UK in a four nations approach.These rules apply to England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Irelanddue to the four nations approach to international travelthe governments have decided to take.Heres everything you need to know about travelling to the UK from abroad...Do I have to do a pre-departure test before flying to the UK From Tuesday December  at am, youwill be required to take a pre-departure test before flying to the UK.This applies to everyone over the age of , whether you are fully vaccinated or not.You must take this test within -hours before your flight to the UK departs.Do I have to do a PCR test when I arrive in the UK Yes,you are fully vaccinated you must take a PCR test within -hours of arriving in the UK.You must isolate until you receive the results of your test.If you are fully vaccinated andthe test is negative, you can leave isolation.What are the travel rules for red listed countries The following countries are currently on the red list:AngolaMalawiMozambiqueZambiaSouth AfricaBotswanaEswatiniLesothoNamibiaNigeriaZimbabwePeople travelling from red listed countries must take a PCR test prior to travel to the UK, isolate in a quarantine hotel when they arrive and take PCR tests on day  and day  of arrival.This applies to anyone travelling from red listed zones, whether vaccinated or not.What are the travel rules for people who are not fully vaccinated If you are not fully vaccinated and travelling to the UK from a non-red listed country, you must:.removetake a COVID- test ndash to be taken in the days before you travel to England book and pay for day  and day  COVID-PCRtestsndash to be taken after arrival in Englandquarantine at home or in the place you are staying for  full daystake your COVID-PCRtests ndash you mustbook these testsbefore you travel

title: covid-scotland-booster-jabs-appear-vaccine-passports-december-9
story: Scotlands deputy first minister confirmed this morning that the Covid booster jab will appear on Scottish vaccine passports for internationaltravel from December .Speaking on Good Morning Scotland, John Swinney said that proof of the booster jab would appear on vaccine passports for international travel from Thursday this week.He added that this would be extended to the domestic vaccine certicationscheme, however this would take slightly longer to implement.When asked whether booster jabs would be included in the vaccine passport scheme, the deputy first minister said: "For international travelit will from  December."And we will expand that for domestic certication but that will take us a little more time to do that. But the critical requirement is for international travel and those changes will be applied from  December."Why is it important that boosters show on vaccine passports To travel to some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.Proof of a booster jab will therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.Who can get a booster jab in Scotland All adults in Scotland will be offered a booster vaccine as advised by the JCVI after results showed a third vaccine signicantly improved protection against serious infection.The booster jabs aim to curb a potentialwave of infections caused by the Omicron iant.So far, everyone aged  and over and people who are clinically vulnerable have been invited to book their booster jabs in Scotland.But soon, everyone over the age of  will beable to book a booster jab.These third doses will be offered no less than three months after the second dose of the vaccine was administered..removeThis time frame between second vaccine and booster jab has been cut from six months to three, as advised by the JCVI.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: tapestry-group-reaching-nationwide-stitchers
story: This follows research carried out by Dr David Caldwell, president of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, who worked for  years with the National Museums of Scotland.He has studied the list of names of Scottish soldiers who died, which is read out at the Old Musselburgh Clubrsquos annual commemoration of the battle at its memorial stone near Wallyford.The revised list has some  names it is hoped MSPs will be enlisted to share them with groups and organisations in their communities to give them the chance to research their ancestors.Roger Knox, chairman of the Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Group, said: ldquoThe names of the fallen at Pinkie, uncovered by David Caldwell, illustrate the wide area of the origin of the force.ldquoExperience of other tapestry constructions has shown that people do show an interest where there is a connection to their own village, estate, family and area.ldquoWe hope that the circulation of the names and places of origin of the fallen will encourage potential stitchers to come forward.Mr Knox said that Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, had offered to circulate details amongst colleagues at the Scottish Parliament.Mr Beattie said: ldquoI am delighted to help in this signicant effort and have reached out to my colleagues in Holyrood to ask them to assist using their contacts with local quilting groups.ldquoI am pleased that I have already received several responses and hope that we can establish interest across Scotland to take part in this fantastic project.Designed by Andrew Crummy, the artist behind the Great Tapestry of Scotland and Battle of Prestonpans Tapestry, the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh Tapestry is being worked on by a group of stitchers under the expert guidance of Liz Neilson.Unlike any of Mr Crummyrsquos other tapestries, the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh Tapestry will have up to six huge .Stitchers have been working on smaller embroideries depicting their favourite parts of Musselburgh and what the town means to them.These will be incorporated into the finished , which will be housed at the Brunton Hall.Pinkie Cleugh was the last pitched battle between Scotland and England, fought on September , .It took place during the Rough Wooing, when the armies of Scotland and England fought to determine who should marry the infant Mary, Queen of Scots.The armies were led by the Earl of Arran, Regent of Scotland, and the Lord Protector of England, the Duke of Somerset, whose aim was to secure the betrothal of nine-year-old Prince Edward, the English heir apparent, to five-year-old Mary.There were , Scottish troops massacred in the rout, which became known as lsquoBlack Saturdayrsquo.Historic Environment Scotland is also reviewing the inventory record for the Battle of Pinkie and would welcome comments from the public.The battle was added to the list of nationally important battlefields in Scotland in .A spokesperson for Historic Environment Scotland said: ldquoWe have updated the inventory record for the Battle of Pinkie battlefield site following a request from a member of the public.ldquoThe record has been updated to reflect new research on the historical information and context of the battle.ldquoWe have added dferent interpretations of features connected to the battle and have updated the maps that accompany the record.ldquoThe Battle of Pinkie, which took place in , is thought to be the largest single battle ever fought in Scotland in terms of numbers of combatants.ldquoAs part of our consultation, which runs until Wednesday, December , we are encouraging members of the public to share their views on the proposed updates to the inventory at consultations.his toricenvironment.scot herit age battle-of-pinkieChanges were made to address the reasons why the Duke of Somerset invaded and the wider aims of the  campaign.Updated information regarding armoury and deployment numbers for the English forces has been included.

title: msp-accuses-bus-bosses-heads-sand-suspended-x5-service
story: Craig Hoy, Conservative South Scotland MSP, claims he contacted Lothian Buses three times to organise a meeting to discuss the future of the service, before he received a response.The X bus was suspended last year by East Coast Buses, a subsidiary of Lothian Buses, following the introduction of national lockdown restrictions.The service ran through North Berwick, Dirleton, Gullane, Aberlady and Longniddry, then directly to Edinburgh via the A.Commuters from Dirleton, Gullane and Aberlady now face an extra hour in their daily commute to Edinburgh using the  bus service, which stops at Prestonpans, Wallyford, Musselburgh and Portobello.An online petition launched by Mr Hoy calling for the reinstatement of the service has now received more than  signatures.Mr Hoy said: ldquoIn early October, my office contacted East Coast Buses, who issued a standard response outlining the reasons for continued withdrawal of the service, including challenges with recruitment, the need to prioritise key services and the focus on delivering the  service.ldquoI recognise these challenges, but I also recognise they apply across all routes across the whole of the Lothians and are not confined to the X route.ldquoAfter a number of residents living in Dirleton, Gullane, Aberlady and Longniddry reached out to me about the X bus, I launched a petition calling for the reinstatement of the service.ldquoI wrote to East Coast Buses on two occasions requesting a face-to-face meeting, and followed this up with a third letter to the interim managing director of Lothian Buses.ldquoLothian Buses is owned by the four Lothian council areas, which includes East Lothian Council. That makes it accountable to the residents of our community.ldquoThe number of signatures on the petition shows the clear strength of feeling in the area about reinstating the X bus.ldquoAt this point, Lothian Buses have their heads buried in the sand ndash they cannot keep ignoring our communities.In a letter to Mr Hoy dated November , Nigel Serafini, interim managing director of Lothian Buses, said it was the companyrsquos ldquopriority to re-establish the X ldquoas soon as driver resource permits.He added: ldquoThe X covers no additional areas that service  does not .ldquoIn contrast, the X is the only service that operates to East Linton, West Barns and Dunbar. Without the X these communities would be without a regular bus service whilst, as explained, the same is not true of Gullane, Aberlady and Dirleton.A spokesperson for East Coast Buses added: ldquoEast Coast Buses is absolutely committed to delivering for all of our customers in East Lothian.ldquoLike many other transport providers at this time, we are in an extremely challenging recruitment market, which, coupled with our safety protocols for colleagues who find themselves in the Covid- track and trace cycle, means that we are experiencing signicant resourcing dficulties in our driving team on a day-to-day basis.ldquoWith limited available resource, we have made the dficult decision to prioritise key services which provide as many transport links as possible throughout East Lothian. In terms of service provision for Gullane and Aberlady, we have focused on delivering service , which provides critical local links along the coast as well as direct travel to Edinburgh.

title: festive-themed-north-berwick-post-boxes-looking-tops
story: Two red Royal Mail post boxes are sporting Christmas-themed bonnets thanks to the painstaking efforts of two town residents.Community council chairman Judy Lockhart-Hunter and friend Linda Digney spent many hours making the crocheted post box toppers after being inspired by similar creations in other parts of the country.Said Judy: "We hoped that we could bring a smile to people and raise some money for the Christmas lights."When we were putting them up quite a few people came over to see what we were doing and the toppers seemed to really make everyone smile."They are a lot of work to make: they took us many many hours over quite a few months, not to mention the sore hands!"We want to keep them going in the future but will probably only do them for Christmas because of the amount of work."We werent  per cent sure they would even fit but we are both so proud of them and thrilled to see that so many people are getting enjoyment from them."The decorated post boxes can be found on the towns Quality Street and on St Baldreds Road.Meanwhile, there is late-night Christmas shopping in North Berwick this evening and in a fortnights time.Local businesses in the town will open until pm tonightand every Thursday untilDecember to allow shoppers more time to purchase gts, with extra festivities provided by North Berwick in Bloom and Christmas carols by North Berwick Gospel Choir.North Berwick in Bloom will serve warm winter punch to get visitors in the festive mood.To donate to the towns Christmas lights fund, go to: GoFundMe nbchristmaslights

title: athelstanefords-christmas-lights-switch-on-take-place-weekend
story: Residents will be able to enjoy refreshments and carols around the Christmas tree to kick off the holiday season.The official village Christmas lights switch-on takes place at Athelstaneford Village Hall from .pm to .pm.Attendees will be treated to a bottle tombola sponsored by Wags and Walkies, a bake sale sponsored by Saltire Property Services, a lucky dip sponsored by Drem Timber and Fencing, tombola sponsored by New Town Dental Care, a gin box sponsored by Fidra Gin, an elf sweetie shop, pocket money toys and a craft stall. Raffle tickets are on sale now.

title: musselburgh-choir-touring-county-weekend
story: The Clark Community Choir is back in action after the easing of Covid- restrictions and, after performing at Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, Santarsquos Grotto at the Ship Inn in Musselburgh, and the Christmas lights switch-on in Tranent last weekend, the group is set to tour the county this Saturday.The singers will be on Musselburgh High Street, beside BM, -.am outside the Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick, .am-.pm at The Mart, East Linton, .-.pm outside Haddington Corn Exchange, .-pm and at the Ship Inn, Musselburgh, -.pm.Suzanne Walker, a committee member, said: ldquoWe are really excited to be out performing for this year, as we havenrsquot been out since March .During the Covid- lockdown, the choir, led by choir leader Kirsty Robertson, kept up regular practice sessions via Zoom, enjoyed online quiz nights, musical evenings and even a Christmas party.ldquoWe were delighted to have our first in-person practice in June this year, said Suzanne.ldquoNewhailes House was kind enough to let us practise on their front lawn on a Sunday evening so we could socially distance but sing together.ldquoI think we even entertained some of the evening walkers.She added: ldquoWe would love to help make this Christmas extra special for everyone.Performances will continue at the following venues: Ship Inn, Musselburgh, Sunday, December , .-pm Ship Inn, Sunday, December , .-pm Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, Saturday, December , -.am Ship Inn, Sunday, December , .-pm.The choir, whose motto is lsquogenerations singing togetherrsquo, was formed in , following the death of Robert Clark, founder of Musselburghrsquos St Ninianrsquos Junior Concert Party in .Mr Clark, a chemistry teacher at both Musselburgh Grammar and Newbattle High Schools, also took children all over Britain and Europe on holidays.He retired at the age of  and, six months after being named Musselburghrsquos Citizen of the Year in , he passed away suddenly and unexpectedly at the age of  ndash just two weeks before a grand reunion was to be held for the concert partyrsquos th birthday.Following the reunion, a choir was formed by former and current concert party members.An invitation was thrown open to the community to join and the group was named the Clark Community Choir in tribute to Mr Clark.The choir exists for anyone of any age, background or ability who enjoys singing, whether they consider themselves a lsquosingaphobicrsquo, an expert or somewhere in between.It seeks to unite generations in a common purpose: singing popular music for pleasure.

title: christmas-lights-switch-ons-impacted-storm-arwen
story: Haddingtonrsquos virtual switch-on on Sunday evening was cancelled as the team of volunteers had to carry out repairs and checks to ensure the lights had not been damaged by the mph winds.Meanwhile, Dunbarrsquos switch-on is yet to take place after the townrsquos High Street was closed on Friday after reports of building damage and fallen chimney pots and slates due to the strong winds.Chris McEwan, chairman of Haddingtonrsquos community council, said volunteers ended up working for  hours on Saturday to ensure all of the lights were in a suitable condition to be switched on.Further lights are to go up before the end of the week after spare parts were ordered.A video has since been posted online showing the town lit up, including new lights on Whittingehame Drive.Mr McEwan said: ldquoThey look fantastic. All the money we saved doing it ourselves was reinvested.ldquoWe did not do anything extra last year because we did not think we could. Two years of saving up and what we saved doing it ourselves was put into Whittingehame Drive.ldquoThere are pound, worth of lights up on Whittingehame Drive and it is looking great. I am so pleased with it but we just ran out of time to do a proper switch-on.The winds threatened to cause substantial damage to Dunbarrsquos lights display, which is always one of the most popular in the county.The lights were not switched on over the weekend, with East Lothian Council confirming a rearranged switch-on could take place from pm this Sunday.Graham Adams, who heads up the team of volunteers responsible for the Christmas lights, was pleased to say that ldquo. per cent of the display would still go ahead.He said: ldquoWe have got new signs up, we have got lights down to the harbour and new lights round the one-way system. It is the biggest display we have had and it is just unfortunate the storm has affected it but there is nothing we can do.

title: residents-take-part-community-light-aberlady
story: Light Up Aberlady, a community project, takes place at pm.The light-up will be filmed by drone and later shared to social media.

title: north-berwicks-restored-barometer-unveiled
story: The barometer ndash installed in the gable of the old granary building by East Lothian Yacht Clubrsquos Commodore Butterworth in about  ndash had seen its wooden housing and surrounding stonework in need of urgent repair.Hugh MacKenzie, a trustee of North Berwick Harbour Trust, said: ldquoIt is hoped that the restored barometer will be an asset to fishermen, sailors and tourists alike, in addition to being a further attraction at the historic North Berwick Harbour.The unveiling of the barometer, which cost about pound, to restore is scheduled for this Saturday at pm.

title: musselburgh-duos-gardening-exploits-see-become-internet-stars
story: Eli Appleby-Donald, , and we KathrynAppleby-Donald, , have created a YouTube channel and website ndash The Kitchen Garden with Eli and Kate ndash aimed at making gardening ldquosimple, easy and fun for everyone.From the garden in the Honest Toun, Eli, a digital teaching specialist at the University of Edinburgh, and Kate, head of collections at the Scottish Parliament, have produced more than  videos which focus on gardening, growing food and flowers.Their YouTube channel now has , subscribers, attracting about , views from  countries.Eli said: ldquoWe had a website and blog that we started back in  when we moved into this house.ldquoAlthough, to be honest, we did it for family to keep them updated and never expected anyone other than our family to read it.ldquoKatersquos mum had been diagnosed with Alzheimerrsquos, so the blog was meant as a way for her to see what we were doing.ldquoWe were really surprised when we started getting messages from folk who had found it and enjoyed it.She said: ldquoWe started making videos to share on the blog, again thinking only a few folk who read the blog would watch them.ldquoBut towards the end of , we started to get a lot more people watching the videos than reading the blog, so I tried to learn a bit more about making videos to make them better.ldquoWhen Covid hit and we all went into lockdown, I really missed being in the classroom but I had been working with students who donrsquot normally delve into the digital world and Irsquod been teaching them to make videos and blog.ldquoI was hearing from them about how much that meant to them to have this outlet while they were locked down and I realised that I was getting something similar from YouTube.Eli said they had done a lot on greenhouse growing because, when they started, they were growing tomatoes and peppers.She added: ldquoI also talk about how to grow from seed to save money because itrsquos a lot cheaper than buying plants.ldquoWersquove done some cooking videos, too ndash things like making passata with the tomatoes yoursquove grown or we did easy sourdough during lockdown.She added: ldquoThe videos are meant as a lsquofriend in the garden with yoursquo idea.ldquoWe only make videos about what we are doing in the garden and specically for growing in Scotland.The couple, who got married in their garden, have covered topics such as mulch, how to sharpen your garden tools, how to get your tomatoes to ripen, how to monitor greenhouse temperatures and composting.Eli said: ldquoIt wasnrsquot until we moved to Musselburgh that I fell in love with gardening.ldquoWhen we bought the house, there werenrsquot really any gardens. The front had been paved over and the back was just a lawn. So, I think we were maybe lucky that we got to design our garden to suit us and start from scratch. It helped fire the passion for gardening, I think.ldquoIrsquove been absolutely astounded at how many amazing folk watch our videos every week. We have had loads of lovely messages from folk saying how much theyrsquove enjoyed learning to garden with us over lockdown and beyond, and how wersquove taken the fear out of it.ldquoThere were even a few messages that made me cry where people have talked about their personal situations and what joy they get from our videos, and how they have made me a part of their weekly ritual.ldquoFolk from all over the world seem to really connect with what we are doing and how we are teaching in our videos, so itrsquos lovely when we get messages telling us what itrsquos been like in their towns and countries, and wersquove made some lovely friends from the US and Canada to Australia, India and even Thailand.ldquoIrsquom so, so glad that folk have found happiness and comfort in our daftness.Catch up with Eli and Kate at youtube c TheKitchenGardenwithEliandKate or thekitchengardenwitheliandkate

title: new-members-scottish-youth-parliament-delighted-get-started
story: The Scottish Youth Parliamentis the democratically elected voice of Scotlandrsquos young people. It provides a national  for young people to discuss issues important to them and bring about the change they wish to see.SYP was influential in helping secure votes for -year-olds in Scotland and has also been a key voice in the campaign for equal marriage through its Love Equally campaign.Voting for new MSYPs took place last month.The two East Lothian constituency places were secured by -year-olds Fraser Davidson and Daniel Scott, both S pupils at North Berwick High School.Meanwhile, the two Midlothian North and Musselburgh constituency MSYPs are Olivia Brown, , and -year-old Callum Gibson.Fraser said: ldquoIrsquom so excited to have been elected as an MSYP for East Lothian.ldquoI want to help promote the voices of every young person in East Lothian and campaign on their behalf for positive change.Daniel added: ldquoI am delighted and honoured to be elected as an MSYP for East Lothian.ldquoI will use my position to promote policies to improve education and the environment as well as other issues my constituents care about. I canrsquot wait to get started.Olivia, who is from Musselburgh and attends St Davidrsquos RC High School in Dalkeith, said: ldquoIrsquom so excited to represent my constituency and begin working with the young people within it.ldquoThrough advocating for the improvement of mental health services, the living wage to be adopted by employers and the cleaning of Musselburghrsquos sea water, I hope to continue to make this constituency the best place for a young person to grow up in.Newbattle High School pupil Callum said: ldquoIrsquove always had a love for politics in and out of school, which led to my discovery of the Scottish Youth Parliament from a friend. It is an opportunity I am very passionate about and I am looking forward to my future with it.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-november-29-december-2-1996-1971-1921
story: years agoAN ANONYMOUS donor was looking to serve up an ace, according to the East Lothian Courier of November , .A mystery benefactor has offered to buy an all-weather tennis court for Belhaven Hill School in Dunbar.The donor used a lawyer to approach the school in the summer, agreeing to fund the building of an astro turf pitch on part of the current playing fields.The schoolrsquos headmaster, Michael Osborne, said: ldquoWe have absolutely no idea who made the donation, but we are extremely grateful for the kind offer.He described the amount of money as ldquosubstantial but declined to disclose the actual figure in accordance with the donorrsquos wishes.Although the gt was intended for a single tennis court, Mr Osborne decided to contribute school cash to increase the area of the pitch.ldquoWe thought we would extend the money to make space for four tennis courts instead of one, he said. years agolsquoTORIES lash outrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier of December , .A bitter two-pronged attack on the Government over the closure of Scotlandrsquos only sugar beet factory came this week from leading East Lothian Conservatives and farmers.For the closure may cause a farm job crisis and force farmers to increase grain acreages against their better judgement.The Conservative Associationrsquos County Committee joined the furious farmers in slamming the Government in a statement issued from their Haddington headquarters.And their views are to be passed to Mr Alick Buchanan-Smith, MP, Scottish Under-Secretary responsible for agriculture.The committee said that the closure of the Cupar Factory could only reflect badly on the Government at a time of high unemployment in Scotland. years agoTHE decline of the fishing trade in Yarmouth was having an impact on Scots workers, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier of December , .The number of girls going to Yarmouth may be lessened in later years, as the Yarmouth fishing is overdone.No less than thirty workers of Scots domicile came before the Yarmouth Magistrates as having no means toto Scotland.The railway fares were granted, but the cause of these workers being stranded ndash with its concurrent dangers ndash will be the matter for an investigation.

title: mary-contini-column-sustainable-christmas
story: We reflect wryly that, often when the immediate present opening is over, it is not unusual to witness the kids distracted with adventures played out with the empty boxes new toys discarded in the corner of the room.I remember the hilarity in our house on Christmas morning in Cockenzie when my brothers, Kevin, Paul, and John Mark, all under  years of age, after an unusually long absence, appeared as Frankenstein and the Incredible Hulk dressed in nothing other than cardboard boxes, toilet paper tubes, red lipstick and black mascara.Their expensive train set, Lego and Fisher-Price garage lay discarded where they had been opened.Those toys have long since been sent to the tip as, I suspect, will many of this yearrsquos toys in the future.Christmas cabins have ed to Haddington town centreDuring the COP climate change conference, very engaged young people were campaigning with great effect to insist governments urgently stop the causes of climate change.They stood with posters and placards frantically shouting for change.They mean it, it is their future after all.The last thing they want are toys which have been transported halfway across the world and made of non-degradable plastic.Fortunately, we have plenty of alternatives on our doorsteps.This year, the Christmas cabins in Haddington are being set up again selling local arts and crafts, gts for all ages and tastes.Cockenzie House is setting up its superb Christmas Fair this weekend, December , as are Stenton and Innerwick communities.Our local high streets are brimming with wonderful independent gt shops fully stocked with locally made treats.We are spoiled for choice. And,you still canrsquot find what you are looking for, an East Lothian Gt Card loaded with lots of money will always be well received.So this Christmas, before you shop, reflect on that toy lsquoelephant in the roomrsquo: it may be made of plastic.
